Graphical abstract In-situ introduced the Fe-vacancies into FeS via one-step pyrolysis and verifies the feasibility of Fe0.96S@C host as catalyst and adsorbent toward polysulfides for the first time. Cation vacancy engineering is considered to be one of the effective methods to solve the issues of shuttling and sluggish redox kinetics of LiPSs owing to the intrinsic tunability of electronic structure. However, cation vacancies are few studied in the Li-S realm due to their complex and rigid preparation methods. In this work, one-step pyrolysis is reported to in situ introduce Fe-vacancies into iron sulfide (Fe0.96S) as a sulfur host. For this host structure, Fe0.96S is first employed as an adsorbent and catalyst in Li-S system. During the carbonization process, a tight contact structure of Fe0.96S crystal and carbon network (Fe0.96S@C) is in situ constructed, and the carbon layer as a conductor provides smooth electrons transfer pathways for redox reactions. Meanwhile, due to the introduction of Fe-vacancies in FeS crystal, the adsorption capability and catalytic effect for LiPSs have been substantially enhanced. Moreover, the presence of Fe0.96S crystal favors the mobility of electron and diffusion of Li+, which is revealed by the experiments and theoretical calculations. Through synergy respective advantages effect of Fe0.96S and carbon, the Fe0.96S@C-S cathode delivers high-rate capability at 5.0 C and stable long-life performance. Even under a high sulfur loading of 3.5 mg/cm2, the durable cyclic stability is still exhibited with the capacity retention of 93% over 400 cycles at 1.0 C, and the coulombic efficiency is ≥98%. Noting that this strategy greatly simplifies the synthetic process of currently known cation-vacancy materials and furnishes a universal mentality for designing both divinable and astonishing new cation-vacancy materials. Keywords Cation vacancy Fe0.96S@C structure Catalytic conversion Lithium-sulfur battery 1 Introduction Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery is equipped with ultra-high theoretical energy density due to the stepwise redox reactions between elemental sulfur and lithium. This rechargeable system is predicted to be one of the most promising substitutes for commercial lithium-ion [1,2]. However, many issues impede the industrialization of Li-S batteries, main including the insulation of S and Li2S/Li2S2, the sluggish solid (S)–liquid (LiPSs)–solid (Li2S/Li2S2) multi-phase conversion kinetics, and the dissolution and shuttling of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) during the cycling process [3,4]. These dams would bring out the low utilization of sulfur species, insufficient rate performance, and obvious capacity decay of Li-S batteries [5,6]. To essentially ameliorate the slow conversion kinetics and relieve the shuttling effect, strenuous strategies have been dedicated to designing and fabricating advanced cathode materials [7–10]. Various materials such as carbonaceous materials [11–14], composites of metal oxides/sulfides/phosphides/nitrides combined with conductive materials [15–21], and multicomponent heterostructures have been proposed as adsorbent and electrocatalyst to trap and catalyze LiPS mediators [22–24]. However, most of these materials are “extrinsic” approaches, which means that the electronic structures of these materials have been unadjusted, thus the improvement in electrochemical performance is limited. Recently, a burgeoning interest focusing on defect engineering in the Li-S realm because this “intrinsic” strategy is based on incorporating defects into the lattice structure, which could tune the atomic and electronic properties of nanomaterials [25–28]. This intrinsic method realizes superior electrochemical performance due to the lower ion or electron diffusion energy barriers and accelerated electrode kinetics [29,30]. Benefiting from these fascinating functionalities, defect engineering is a promising strategy for inhibiting LiPS behavior and accelerating redox action in Li-S systems. Intentionally creating vacancies is regarded as one of the most essential defect engineering strategies for modifying geometrical and chemical configurations of compounds [25]. Benefiting from the plentiful localized electrons, vacancies are considered active sites for immobilizing and catalyzing the conversions of various intermediates in electrocatalytic reactions such as water splitting [31–33], carbon dioxide reduction [34], rechargeable battery system [35,36], even in the gas sensing field [37]. For example, Chen et al. developed the defective Fe3− x C as a sulfur immobilizer to pursue strong LiPS adsorption and catalyzation because the existence of Fe vacancy in Fe3− x C neatens the Fe electronic structure [27]. To date, lots of research have been conducted to explore the correlation between anion vacancies and catalytic effect [38–40], whereas there are few studies focused on the cation vacancies due to their complex and difficult preparation methods [41]. In general, the anion vacancies could be effectively introduced via annealing corresponding metal compounds in a reductive gas [42,43]. However, because of the higher formation energy than anion vacancies, an energy-intensive process is indispensable for the creation of cation vacancies [31]. In addition, the method of introducing defects is hidebound, often involving corrosive/destructive procedures which are uncontrolled at the atomic scale [44,45]. As a novel example, Huang et al. proposed Fe atoms in the cubic Ni3FeN were removed via polysulfides in situ etching at the atomic scale, resulting in an active Ni3Fe1− δ N phase as kinetic regulators for high-performance Li-S cell [41]. However, such an etching method is individual, which limited its application in other energy storage fields. Thus, it is desirable to propose a facile, universal, and absence of corrosion method for cation vacancies formation in the catalysts, which could catalyze different reaction systems. Herein, we proposed and validated a facile and feasible method for in situ introduction of Fe-vacancies into hexagonal iron sulfide (Fe1− x S, x = 0.04) as LiPS catalyst and adsorbent. To the best of our knowledge, Fe0.96S is employed for the first time as the sulfur host material. The synthesis of Fe0.96S is based on the one-step calcination of Fe-mercaptobenzothiazole (MBT-Fe). During the pyrolysis process, the phase separation occurs between carbon (C) and Fe0.96S forming Fe0.96S crystal successfully but without stripping from the C phase due to the coordination of Fe2+ and MBT. For the composite of Fe0.96S and C (Fe0.96S@C), the Fe0.96S layer with Fe-vacancies fast the diffusion of Li-ion and is expected to effectively catalyze the conversion of LiPSs. Moreover, the conductive carbon layer not only acts as the electronic transfer pathway but also supplies abundant electrons to the Fe0.96S, because of the closely bound between Fe0.96S and C layer. The coordination between metal cations Fe2+ and organic ligands mercaptobenzothiazole (MBT) is shown in Fig. 1 . Profiting from the synergistic effects of the Fe0.96S and conductive C during the cyclic process (Fig. 1), the Fe0.96S@C-based electrodes deliver excellent electrochemical performance. The cathode (Fe0.96S@C-S, 75.5 wt% sulfur, 2.5 mg/cm2) achieves a discharge capacity of 700 mAh/g over 400 cycles. Even with a higher sulfur loading, the excellent cyclic stability is still maintained, the capacity reservation is up to 93% over 400 cycles at 1.0 C, and the coulombic efficiency is ≥98%. Beside Fe element, MBT could coordinate with other transition metal atoms (such as Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, and Mn) and the corresponding metal sulfides are obtained after heating treatment. Thus, this synthesis method is not only suitable for the Li-S system but also can be extended to other research fields. 2 Experimental 2.1 The synthesis of composites The reagents mentioned in these experiments are analytical grade. We without further purification. 2.1.1 Preparation of Fe0.96S@C sample The precursors were synthesized using a one-step complexation. Typically, 6 mL sodium mercaptobenzothiazole (MBT-Na) aqueous solution (50% in water, ∼3.6 g MBT-Na) and 1.89 g FeCl2·4H2O were mixed in 100 mL deionized water with a 2:1 mole ratio. The iron(II)mercaptobenzothiazole (MBT-Fe) was formed immediately and precipitated as a yellow-brown deposit. Quickly stir the above yellow-brown mixed solution for 1 h with 600 r/min. Then, static precipitated for 12 h. The obtained deposit was filtrated and washed repetitively using deionized water. Following the yellow-brown powder was dried overnight. Lastly, the dried MBT-Fe was carbonized under the Ar atmosphere, for 1 h at 700 °C. 2.1.2 Preparation of other metal sulfides The precursors of other metal sulfides were obtained using the same synthetic method. Replaced FeCl2 with ZnCl2, NiCl2, CuCl2, MnCl2 and CoCl2, respectively. Pyrolysis conditions were 700 °C for 1 h, and similarly, obtained a series of metal sulfides. 2.1.3 Preparation of C sample As a contrast sample, the pure C composite without Fe0.96S was obtained via dissolving Fe0.96S into an acid solution. Fe0.96S@C composite was immersed in the 1.2 M hydrochloric to remove the Fe0.96S crystal. Then the sample was separated and repeatedly washed using deionized water. Finally, the sample was dried at 60 °C. 2.1.4 Preparation of Fe0.96S@C-S, C-S composites The as-prepared Fe0.96S@C or C powder was uniformly mixed with sublimed sulfur. The weight% of S is 80%. These hybrids were treated at 155 °C in tube furnaces using 12 h. Finally, the Fe0.96S@C-S or C-S composites were obtained. 2.2 Characterization The chemical structures of MBT-Fe precursors before and after pyrolysis were characterized by IR (VERTEX80v) spectroscopy. The crystal structural information was obtained using an Xpert3 Powder X-ray Diffractometer (XRD) using Cu K α. The scanning interval is between 5°–80° and the scanning speed is 2.0–5.0°/min. The chemical states of these samples were employed Thermo Fisher Nexsa X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Morphology characterizations of these products were detected with Nova NanoSEM 450 scanning electron microscope (SEM). The lattice fringe images were recorded using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20). Elements of these composite were identified by an energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). Thermogravimetric (TG) curves were tested to monitor the decomposition of MBT-Fe precursor, the sulfur contents, and the contents of Fe0.96S and C component on Netzsch TG209F1. The specific surface area and pore structure of the material were measured by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method using the Quantachrome Autosorb IQ instrument. An Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) test was carried out to identify the atomic ratio of Fe/S on Agilent 7700X & Agilent 7800 (MS). Four-probe tests were conducted to explore the electrical conductivity of as-prepared samples using the instrument ST-2258C. 2.3 Adsorption test 2.3.1 Visual adsorption measurement The as-prepared Fe0.96S@C, C samples (10 mg) were weighed, and lithium polysulfide (LiPS) solution was taken with 1000 µL. Mixed them and ultrasonic dispersion 5 min. Then static put for 24 h in the glovebox. The above LiPS solution was obtained via dissolving Li metal and sublimed sulfur into the electrolyte. Then diluting this LiPS solution using the electrolyte at a volume ratio of 1:9, then the above LiPS solution was prepared. 2.3.2 The XPS and XRD tests After the static adsorption test, the upper LiPS solution was poured away by centrifugation, and the remaining Fe0.96S@C powder was used for the XPS and XRD tests to demonstrate the interaction between LiPSs and Fe0.96S@C composite. 2.4 Li2S nucleation and precipitation tests A Li2S8 catholyte (0.25 M) was obtained via mixing elemental sulfur and white Li2S powder. Hydrophobic carbon cloths (CC) were employed as the substrate to coat the Fe0.96S@C and C hosts. CC-Fe0.96S@C and CC-C acted as cathodes and metal Li served as an anode. 20 μL Li2S8 catholyte was first added to the CC-Fe0.96S@C and CC-C electrodes, then electrolyte (20 μL) without Li2S8 was distributed onto the side of Li. The cells were discharged at a galvanostatic current (0.112 mA) until the potential became 2.06 V. Following kept potentiostatically at a potential of 2.05 V until the current density dropped to 0.01 mA. 2.5 Details of theoretical calculation The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted using the Materials Studio (MS). The maximum force, maximum displacement, and energy convergence accuracy were 2 × 10−3 Ha/Å, 5 × 10−3 Ha/Å, and 1 × 10−5 Ha. As the basic setting of double numerical polarization (DNP), the value is 3.5. 10−6 Ha was a set of self-consistent loop energy. The smearing was applied at 0.005 Ha. The k-point sample of Monkhorst-Pack is 5 × 5 × 1 for the geometry optimization and 10 × 10 × 1 for the electronic optimization. The global orbital cutoff radius was 5.0 Å. The (102) plane of FeS crystal was calculated. The Fe0.96S (102) plane with Fe-vacancies was designed by removing iron atoms from the intact FeS surface. For adsorption energies on Fe0.96S, 2 × 2 supercells (containing 64 iron atoms) were constructed with the vacuum layer of 18 Å. The adsorption energies (E ads) of Li2Sn on the Fe0.96S (102) surface were calculated as E a d s = E t o t a l - E L i 2 S n - E F e 0.96 S where E t o t a l , E L i 2 S n , and E F e 0.96 S represent the total energies of the slab, the energies of Li2S n (n = 1, 2, 6, 8) cluster, and the energies of the Fe0.96S slab, respectively. 2.6 The electrochemical tests The working electrodes of Li-S cells were obtained via mixing the Fe0.96S@C-S or C-S composite, poly(vinylidene fluoride) binder, and commercial conductive agent (8:1:1 by weight). The mixture was made into a fine slurry using the N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) solution. The working cathodes were prepared after dried at 60 °C overnight. diameter of C-S electrode is 12 mm, and the total area of sulfur cathode is 1.13 cm2. CR2032 cells were assembled using the Fe0.96S@C-S or C-S cathode, Celgard separators (PP), and Li anodes, the N/P is 28. The electrolyte consisting of a mixture of 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) and 1,2-dimethoxymethane (DME) (1:1 by volume) with bis (trifluoromethane) sulfonamide lithium salt (1.0 M) and 2.0% LiNO3. The cell test employed the Neware Battery Measurement System at 27.0 °C. The general ratio of E/S is 20 µL/mg, but under lean electrolyte, the values are equal to 5, 6, and 7 µL/mg, respectively. The CV information was gathered by the CHI660E Electrochemical workstation. Impedance test was proceeded with frequency from 10−1 Hz to 106 Hz. The performance of long-term cycles and rates were obtained by Neware test system. 3 Results and discussion The integrated details of Fe0.96S@C sample are schematically shown in Fig. 1. The tightly contacted structure of the FeS catalyst with Fe-vacancies and conductive C network was obtained in situ via a one-step pyrolysis process. Firstly, yellow-brown iron mercaptobenzothiazole (MBT-Fe) was prepared by a complex reaction, which FeCl2 and sodium mercaptobenzothiazole (MBT-Na) as the reactants. MBT-Na is usually served as a corrosion inhibitor for iron, aluminum, and copper products in the industry [46], and is easy to coordinate with transition metal atoms [47]. This process was proved using X-ray Diffractometer (XRD), Infrared (IR), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterizations. Fig. S1 shows XRD patterns of MBT-Fe, the crystal phase is completely different from the MBT-Na, indicating that the crystal phase has changed. The IR spectra show the information of molecular functional groups in MBT-Fe and MBT-Na. As shown in Fig. S2, corresponding peaks of the benzene ring (3100–3000, 1600–1450, 1000–700 cm−1) and the characteristic peaks of thiophene (1440–1460, 1160–1000, 850–820 cm−1) are discovered in the spectra both of MBT-Fe and MBT-Na [47], indicating that the chemical functional groups stay the same. However, these functional groups have a redshift during the process, indicating that after MBT− is coordinated with Fe2+. Different from the electrostatic attraction between MBT− and Na+, the covalent bonds are dominant between Fe2+ and MBT−, which is stronger. Moreover, The FeS bonds in XPS (Fig. S4c and d) further prove the complexation between Fe2+ and MBT− [48]. As shown in thermogravimetry (TG) results, the thermal degradation curves of MBT-Fe were detected under an N2 atmosphere (Fig. S3). The weight drops sharply at a temperature from 240 to 400 °C, which is associated with the volatilization of fragments that are not covalently interacted with the thermostable network. After 400 °C, the newly established texture could steady the carbonization product and the weight loses tardy with increasing temperature. The high residual quantity at 800 °C of 40.12% could be ascribed to the Fe-based nonvolatile inorganic components coordinated with organic ligands that derive a thermostable texture during the carbonization [49]. Moreover, the released reductive gas (such as H2S), could convert the Fe precursor into Fe0.96S during the pyrolysis process [33]. In parallel, a carbon substrate was in-situ obtained, which closely contacted with a large area of Fe0.96S crystal due to the complexation between MBT− and Fe2+. Fig. S4 shows the evolution of constituents and chemical bonds from MBT-Fe to Fe0.96S@C composite, using the XPS technique. The elements of carbon, sulfur, nitrogen, and iron were observed in full spectra (Fig. S4a). Without other elements was detected during the transformation process. Fig. S4(b) compares the C 1s XPS spectra of MBT-Fe and Fe0.96S@C. The peaks corresponding to the CS bond (at 288.8 eV) disappeared in the Fe0.96S@C spectrum, indicating that the CS bonds were broken during the pyrolysis process [50]. Fig. S4(c) shows the results of Fe 2p, the position of peaks at 711.6 and 725.2 eV [51], suggesting that the Fe atoms in MBT-Fe are in the form of Fe2+. After the thermal decomposition process, new peaks of Fe3+ in Fe 2p were detected at 707.4 eV (Fe 2p3/2) [52], indicating that the pyrolysis process introduces Fe vacancies results in the increase of chemical valence from Fe2+ to Fe3+. Fig. 3(b) further compares the S 2p XPS spectra, the peak positions of Fe-S (162.1 eV S 2p3/2) and SC (164.0 eV S 2p3/2) have shifted [53], indicating that the chemical environments around the sulfur atoms have changed. Additionally, after the pyrolysis process, there are new pair peaks of SO/SO bonds at 167.2 eV (S 2p3/2), that should be ascribed to the oxidation of FeS bonds in air. The crystal information of the Fe0.96S@C product is characterized via XRD, the result as shown in Fig. 2 (a), which shows the generation of hexagonal Fe0.96S crystal. The clear diffraction peaks are well-indexed to PDF # 50-1788 with a space group of P63/mmc (194). Compared to the hexagonal FeS (PDF # 49-1632, P63/mmc), the diffraction peaks of Fe0.96S have a blueshift, which indicates that the Fe-vacancies result in the altering of interplanar spacing. The broad peak at around 22° should belong to the carbon peak. ICP-MS test is carried out to further identify the atomic ratio of Fe/S (Table S1). The value is equal to 0.964, which is a good agreement with XRD result and further declares there are Fe-vacancies existing in Fe0.96S. Fig. 2(b and c) shows the morphology of as-synthesized Fe0.96S@C with unique nanosheet units, which were carbonization at 700 °C for 1 h. The Fe0.96S crystal and carbon substrate were observed using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM). Fe0.96S crystal is loaded on the carbon substrate with a large area rather than in the forms of nanoclusters, which is in favor of adsorbing and catalyzing the conversion of LiPSs (Fig. 2d). At a higher magnification, the obvious lattice fringes are observed with a d-spacing of 0.208 nm, which should be assigned to (102) planes of Fe0.96S. (Fig. 2e). The poorly crystallized region should be ascribed to the derivative from carbonized MBT, which will be proved later. This compact construction of Fe0.96S crystal and C network is supposed to reinforce the anchoring of S and LiPS species without obstructing electron/ion transfer and conversion kinetics. In Fig. 2(f–j), the elemental mapping region is marked by an orange square. The uniformly elemental distribution of Fe, S, C, and N in Fe0.96S@C nanosheets are shown. The existing form of the C layer in Fe0.96S@C composite is further indicated, which deliberately dissolved Fe0.96S@C in dilute hydrochloric acid solution. After being etched, the diffraction peaks of the Fe0.96S crystal disappear. The remaining broader peak consistent with carbon turns into explicit (Fig. S5a). The results of HR-TEM images (Fig. S5d) reveal that using the etched method could effectively remove the sulfide while the carbon is reserved. Because of the corrosion of Fe0.96S without damaging the carbon frameworks, thus left carbon inherits the morphology of the nanosheet (Fig. S5b and c). To clarify the carbon phase, Raman characterization was carried out. In the Raman spectra (Fig. S6), two remarkable peaks are exhibited at 1370 and 1580 cm−1, which correspond to the D band and G band, respectively [54]. The I D /I G value of C is 0.6, indicating that the proportion of graphitized carbon in the sample is higher than that of amorphous. The contents of Fe0.96S and C in Fe0.96S@C is confirmed using TG test (Fig. S7), which is 53.61% and 46.39%, respectively. To prove the good electrical conductivity of C network, four-probe tests were conducted. The results in Table S2 show that the good conductivity of as-prepared C is analogous to the commercial carbon (Super P), which is conducive to speeding up electron transfer and improving reaction kinetics of Fe0.96S@C electrode. To investigate the application possibility of Fe0.96S@C serving as a sulfur host in the Li-S system, the Fe0.96S@C-S cathode composites were obtained via physical immersion of sulfur into Fe0.96S@C spaces. The XRD pattern (Fig. S8a) shows the characteristic peaks of sulfur, which agree with PDF # 78-1889, proving the successful combination of sulfur and Fe0.96S@C. TG curve in Fig. S8(b) discloses the high sulfur content of Fe0.96S@C-S cathode is ∼75.5 wt%. It is noted that after S immersion, the nanosheet morphology in Fe0.96S@C-S is well maintained as exposed using the TEM image in Fig. S9(a). The sulfur nanoparticles can homogeneously deposit on the Fe0.96S@C composite, without any agglomeration. HAADF-STEM and the result of elemental mapping for Fe0.96S@C-S further declare the uniform distribution of S as well as the elements of Fe, N, and C (Fig. S9b–f). After the incorporation of sulfur, the BET surface area of Fe0.96S@C-S plummeted from 135.47 to 9.09 m2/g, along with a decreased pore volume from 0.581 to 0.052 cm3/g. As shown in Fig. S10, the various pores in the Fe0.96S@C are also filled with sulfur, which is conducive to achieving the high S loading and rapid charge and mass transfer during the electrochemical reaction. On the contrary, the C@S cathode was synthesized similarly, and the high content of sulfur is 78.5 wt% (Fig. S11). A series of electrochemical tests were operated, in order to investigate the performance of Fe0.96S@C-S and C-S electrodes in Li-S cells. In Fig. 3 (a), the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) analyses were used to assess the impact of Fe0.96S@C on charge transfer. In Nyquist data, the semicircle means the interfacial resistance (R ct), which is shown in the high-frequency region. The value primarily is contributed by the charge transfer [55]. The R ct value matching to the Fe0.96S@C electrode is 29 Ω, which contracts in comparison with the C electrode (40 Ω) before cycling, implying the faster charge migration across the interface of electrolyte/S/Fe0.96S@C. In the catalytic-conductive Fe0.96S@C compact structure, the chemical affinity of S species is more favorable to charge transport than that in the carbon matrix, because the rich Fe-vacancies in Fe0.96S catalyst helps to accelerate the diffusion of Li-ion. This point would be further represented in the following discussion. Fig. 3(b) exhibits the typical cyclic voltammetry (CV) profiles of the Fe0.96S@C-S cathode during the first five cycles. The cathodic scanning located at around 2.31 V and 2.04 V is attributed to the reduction of the elemental sulfur to the long-chain LiPSs and short-chain ones, respectively [56]. In the succedent anodic peaks, two peaks are relevant to the oxidative process of short-chain LiPSs to the long-chain and finally to sulfur [57]. In contrast, only one peak is examined at above 2.4 V for the C-S cathode (Fig. S12) due to the limitation of electrode catalytic. For the cell with Fe0.96S@C-S electrode, during the first five cycles, the curves show obvious overlap but no significant changes in peak position are examined, suggesting the crucial reversibility. However, the oxidation peak of the C-S cathode undergoes a shift toward higher potential owing to the severe polarization after the first cycle. The rate performance of Fe0.96S@C-S and C-S electrodes was assessed at the rates from 0.1 to 5.0 C under S loading of 1.8 mg/cm2 and returning to 4.0, 3.0, 1.5 C and 0.5 C (1.0 C = 1675 mA/g, E/S = 20 µL/mg, Fig. 3c). Evidently, the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode delivers superior rate performance than the C-S electrode under different current densities. Based on Fe0.96S@C-S electrode, at 0.5 C, 1.0 C, 1.5 C, 2.0 C, 3.0 C and 4.0 C, the discharge specific capacity is as high as 809, 636, 623, 603, 557, 507 mAh/g, respectively. Even current density is up to 5.0 C, an outstanding reversible capacity of 420 mAh/g is shown. The high capacities can be quickly restored when suffering a high rate of cycling and reverting to the lower rate. The endurable and reversible rate of Fe0.96S@C-S electrode benefits from the strong adsorption-catalysis interaction between Fe0.96S and LiPSs. Fig. 3(d) and Fig. S13 show the corresponding discharge–charge curves of the Fe0.96S@C-S and C-S cathodes under different current densities with a potential range of 1.8–3.0 V. The higher discharge plateau represents the conversion from S8 to long-chain LiPSs. The lower discharge plateau conforms with the conversion from long-chain to short-chain ones, including insoluble Li2S2/Li2S [58]. Furthermore, the charge plateaus correspond to the conversion from short-chain LiPSs to Li2S8/S8, which is consistent with the CV curves. For the cell based on the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode, a remarkably steady discharge plateau at around 1.91 V can be sighted even under the highly 5.0 C. In contrast, the C-S electrode has no obvious discharge plateau at 4.0 C, and it also shows a larger polarization at each current density. Compared with the C-S electrode (ΔV 2 = 162.7 mV), the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode reveals a lower voltage hysteresis (ΔV 1 = 131.7 mV), at 0.1 C (Fig. 4 a). The lower ΔV indicates due to the synergism between Fe0.96S and C components, the relatively faster conversion kinetics and a much better polarization have been obtained, and eventually increase the specific capacity of the Li-S battery [55]. Noting that the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode also shows a lower activation barrier in the charging process (Fig. 4a, insert data), suggesting the higher catalytic ability and the faster redox kinetics with low charge transfer resistance [59]. Correspondingly, Fig. 3(f) exhibits the higher specific capacities of Fe0.96S@C-S electrode at both the low and high plateaus, even at a higher rate, which further proves the catalytic ability of Fe0.96S@C. Such an effective catalytic ability and high reversibility also endow Fe0.96S@C-S with ultra-stable cycling performance. As displayed in Fig. 3(e), the initial discharge capacity of Fe0.96S@C-S is 724 mAh/g with sulfur loading of 2.2 mg/cm2, at 0.5 C. After 400 cycles, the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode delivers 816 mAh/g, with coulombic efficiencies (CE) of almost 100%, suggesting its effective inhibition on LiPS shuttling. Instead of decreasing, the rising discharge capacity should be attributed to the synergistic effect of the fast catalytic reaction kinetics and ion/electron transfer in the working electrode. In obvious contrast, the C-S electrode undergoes a fast capacity fade of 308 mAh/g with a decay rate of 0.138% per cycle over 400 cycles. Because of the lack of polar catalytic sites and fast ion diffusion, the C-S-based cell loses capacity rapidly. In addition, the initial capacity of Fe0.96S@C-S (724 mAh/g) is higher than that of the C-S (689 mAh/g) electrode, which further demonstrates the higher sulfur utilization of the Fe0.96S@C host. To meet the practical demand for the high energy density of Li-S batteries, high sulfur loading of 3.5 mg/cm2 and a high current density of 3.0 C was fabricated and tested, the corresponding long-term cycling is displayed in Fig. 3(g). The Fe0.96S@C-S cathode displays high-capacity retention of 93% over 400 cycles, with high sulfur loading of 3.5 mg/cm2 at 1.0 C, indicating the potential for practical application. Interestingly, the discharge specific capacity exhibits an upward trend due to the effective catalytic conversion of Fe0.96S@C for LiPSs even under high current density (3.0 C). The superior electrochemical performance of the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode is ascribed to the close contact catalysis-conduction structure of the Fe0.96S layer-C layer, which not only traps the LiPSs via chemical affinity, catalyzes the reversible conversion of the intermediates (Fe0.96S layer), but also promotes Li-ion transfer via the rich Fe-vacancies, effectively improve the conductivity of the electrodes (C layer). More practical electrodes have been explored. When the sulfur loading increases to >5.0 mg/cm2 and the E/S decreases to <7 µL/mg, the electrodes still show the rechargeable behavior of Li-S systems. As shown in Fig. S14, the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode with a sulfur loading of 5.4 mg/cm2 and E/S ratio of 7.0 µL/mg delivers an initial discharge specific capacity of 936 mAh/g at 0.1 C with a highly areal capacity of 4.5 mAh/cm2. This reversible capacity is still retained at 724 mAh/g after 200 cycles with a decay rate of 0.095%. Noting that high loading would aggravate the viscosity of the insufficient electrolyte and severely reduces the kinetics of cells. We reduced the amount of electrolyte (from 7 to 6, 5 μL/mg) and increased the sulfur loading (7.0 mg/cm2), the Fe0.96S electrodes still exhibit excellent long-cycle stability and the coulombic efficiency is higher than 96%, suggesting the suppressed shuttle effect and effectively catalytic effect of Fe0.96S. These results are further verified by the two flat discharge platforms in charge–discharge curves of different cells, indicating the comparable reaction kinetics in the Fe0.96S cathode (Fig. S14d). To better describe and understand the underlying mechanism of the excellent cycling/rate performance achieved for the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode, the S-anchoring and redox kinetics advantages were investigated. The Li+ diffusion coefficient (D Li +) was evaluated through CV tests at different scan rates from 0.1 to 0.5 mV/s to verify the catalysis effect. As shown in Fig. 4(b) and Fig. S15(a), with the scan rate increases, the reduction peaks (C-I and C-II) shift to lower potentials and the oxidation peaks (A-I and A-II) tend to higher ones. The fast kinetics was confirmed via analyzing these CV curves using the Randles–Sevick equation [60,61]. I p e a k = 2.69 × 10 5 n 1.5 A D L i 0.5 v 0.5 C L i where the I peak indicates the value of peak current (A), A means the cathode area (cm2), n is 2, represents the number of electrons in the reaction, C Li indicates the concentration of Li-ion in the electrolyte, v is the scan rate (mV/s). According to this equation, using the linear fitting between the values of peak current (I peak) versus the square root of scanning rate (ν) could calculate the corresponding D Li + value, as shown in Fig. 4(c) and Fig. S15(b). The D Li + value based on the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode is as high as 4.43 × 10−7 cm2/s for Peak A-I, Peak C-I is 8.06 × 10−8 cm2/s, and Peak C-II is 8.36 × 10−8 cm2/s, respectively. These values are much higher than the C-S electrode for both the redox peaks (Fig. 4d), indicating the accelerated diffusion kinetics for Li+ from the Fe0.96S crystal during the redox processes. We further compare the CV of Fe0.96S@C-S and C-S electrodes when the scanning rate is 0.1 mV/s. Although the position of cathodic peaks is similar, the Fe0.96S@C-S electrode shows a larger current value, indicating its conversion kinetics advantages. The oxidative peak A-I of Fe0.96S@C-S displays more negative potential in comparison to the C-S electrode, testifying to a smaller overpotential (0.238 V) for the oxidizing of polysulfides for the former, which is consistent with the charging process (Fig. S16) [62]. In theory, the conversion from soluble LiPSs to solid Li2S2/Li2S contributes a large portion of capacity, and this process represents the rate-determining step of the whole reduction. Thus, to directly reflect the catalytic effect of Fe0.96S layers for the conversion of soluble LiPSs to solid Li2S, Li2S nucleation/deposition experiments were conducted, which is developed by Chiang et al. [63] (Fig. 4e and f). The hosts of Fe0.96S@C and C loaded on carbon cloth (CC) are wetted by Li2S8 catholyte (0.25 M) [22]. Based on this method, the salient current peaks display for the Fe0.96S@C and C electrodes, indicating the efficient deposit of Li2S occurs. Results show that Li2S nucleation capacity on Fe0.96S@C is 244 mAh/g, which is higher than that on C (194 mAh/g). C electrode has a lower capacity and peaks current as a consequence of absenting effective catalyst. Noted that a shorter nucleation time means a lower diffusion of LiPSs and a more effectively catalytic conversion. Clearly, compared to the C electrode, the Fe0.96S@C shows a faster onset of nucleation, and a higher catalytic efficiency for soluble LiPS conversion. The strong S-anchoring of the Fe0.96S layer was confirmed by combining the visual discrimination and the XPS results in Fig. 5 . Adding 10 mg of Fe0.96S@C or residual C after corrosion of Fe0.96S to modulate LiPS solution for 24 h. As a comparison, the blank LiPS solution is also provided without any adsorbent. In the sealed transparent vials with the addition of Fe0.96S@C, the LiPS color changes to almost completely colorless, indicating considerable adsorption of LiPS species by the Fe0.96S@C sample (Fig. 5a). Contrarily, LiPS with C displays yellow but is lighter than the blank LiPS solution, because the main polar sites of Fe0.96S were etched away. The residual N atom in the conductive carbon matrix leads to insignificant adsorption. The interaction between LiPS species and Fe0.96S is detected by comparing the results of XPS before and after adsorbing LiPSs (Fig. 5b and c). In particular, the Fe0.96S@C was dried under vacuum after visual LiPS static adsorption. Then, serves as a typical sample for XPS measurement. After contact with LiPSs, the binding energy of FeS bonds in Fe0.96S have decreased (Fig. 5b) [64,65]. This is because of the forming of strong chemical interaction between Fe0.96S adsorbent and LiPSs, indicating electrons are moving between LiPS species and the Fe atoms. But the crystal phases of Fe0.96S have not changed (Fig. 5a), indicating that LiPSs interact with Fe0.96S through chemical bonds without impacting the crystal structure of Fe0.96S. Coincidentally, new pairs of peaks at 168.9/170.1 eV are expanded in the S 2p spectrum, which should belong to polythionate (Fig. 5c) [66]. Generally, the generation of polythionate resulted from the redox process between LiPSs and Fe0.96S or the air during the XPS measurement. The peaks of S 2p in metal sulfide shift to the higher binding energy, this is in keeping with the result of Fe 2p, which further proves the strong interaction between Fe0.96S and LiPSs [67]. Besides, in the Li 1s spectrum, the LiN bonds are observed as shown in Fig. S17, further indicating the doped N atoms could chemical anchor the LiPSs is consistent with the visual adsorption results [68]. In order to further explain the above adsorption and restriction of Fe0.96@C on LiPSs at the atom level, theoretical calculations are implemented to simulate the binding condition of LiPSs on the Fe-deficient Fe0.96S (102) surface. Figs. S18 and S19 exhibit the optimized configurations of Fe0.96S (102) surface and LiPS molecular. As a comparison, the adsorption energies of LiPS species on FeS (102) surface have also been simulated, as shown in Fig. S20. Fig. 5(d, e) and Fig. S21 show the adsorption situations of Li2S, Li2S2, Li2S6, and Li2S8 molecules on the Fe0.96S (102) surface, respectively. After adsorption, the average distances of LiS bonds in Li2S and Li2S2 increase from 2.10 to 2.31 Å and 2.26 to 2.60 Å, respectively, suggesting the synchronous reduction of interactions between S2− or S2 2− and Li+ ions due to the chemical interaction of LiPSs and Fe0.96S. Moreover, the Li2S2 adsorption on Fe0.96S increased the SS bond length from 2.22 Å to 2.25 Å, indicating the easier decomposing of the SS bond and promoted oxidation of Li2S/Li2S2 upon charge reactions. Given the similar terminal S and Li atoms in the Li2S/Li2S2 and other long-chain LiPSs, the above analysis of LiS and SS bond lengths clearly exhibit that Fe0.96S provide stronger chemical interaction for LiPSs and decreases the bond energies could favor the catalytic redox reaction of LiPSs [15]. The relevant adsorption energies of LiPSs on the Fe0.96S and FeS surface were shown in Fig. 5(f). The adsorption energies between Li2S, Li2S2, Li2S6, Li2S8, and Fe0.96S crystals are −2.08, −4.13, −1.54, and −5.33 eV, respectively, further indicating that the introduction of Fe-vacancies in FeS crystal substantially enhanced the adsorption capability for LiPSs. DFT calculation also revealed the reduced bandgap upon introduction of Fe-vacancies into the semi-conductor FeS to form Fe0.96S, suggesting the favorable electron mobility of Fe0.96S crystal (Fig. S22). Through the above series of experiments and theoretical calculations, the Fe-vacancies Fe0.96S@C composite with a continuous contact interface has been proved to boost the redox kinetics of LiPS species and improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S cells. We further explore the universality of this simple and feasible synthesis method using different transition metals. Similarly, employing MBT-Na as organic ligand, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, and Mn2+ as the metal atoms, respectively. The precipitates were obtained with different colors. After carbonization under 700 °C for 1 h, the as-prepared samples were characterized by XRD, which is shown in Figs. S23, S24. The results of XRD reveal all the pyrolysis products are corresponding to metal sulfides and carbon composites. In consideration of the extraordinary electrochemical performance of Fe0.96S@C for Li-S batteries, these metal sulfides-carbon composites could be employed as energy storage materials. 4 Conclusions In summary, we successfully introduced Fe-vacancies into FeS crystal via a sample one-step method. A compact catalysis-conduction structure of Fe0.96S crystal and carbon substrate was facilely fabricated via one-step pyrolysis. The experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that Fe0.96S@C composite as a sulfur encapsulant possesses strong chemical adsorption and rapid catalytic conversion kinetics for dissolved LiPSs as well as fast diffusion of Li-ion. Consequently, Fe0.96S@C-S cathode exhibits a high sulfur utilization, superior rate performance (5.0 C, 420 mAh/g), and remarkable cycling stability with 95% capacity retention over 400 cycles at 0.5 C. Even with 3.5 mg/cm2 high loading sulfur, the excellent cyclic stability is still achieved. When the sulfur loading increases to >5.0 mg/cm2 and the E/S decreases to <7 µL/mg, the electrodes still show the rechargeable behavior of Li-S systems. This feasible and universal method of creating cationic vacancies in catalysts not only enriches the synthetic approach of defect engineering but also provides the possible application of defect engineering in various fields. coredata.dc:description: Cation vacancy engineering is considered to be one of the effective methods to solve the issues of shuttling and sluggish redox kinetics of LiPSs owing to the intrinsic tunability of electronic structure. However, cation vacancies are few studied in the Li-S realm due to their complex and rigid preparation methods. In this work, one-step pyrolysis is reported to in situ introduce Fe-vacancies into iron sulfide (Fe0.96S) as a sulfur host. For this host structure, Fe0.96S is first employed as an adsorbent and catalyst in Li-S system. During the carbonization process, a tight contact structure of Fe0.96S crystal and carbon network (Fe0.96S@C) is in situ constructed, and the carbon layer as a conductor provides smooth electrons transfer pathways for redox reactions. Meanwhile, due to the introduction of Fe-vacancies in FeS crystal, the adsorption capability and catalytic effect for LiPSs have been substantially enhanced. Moreover, the presence of Fe0.96S crystal favors the mobility of electron and diffusion of Li+, which is revealed by the experiments and theoretical calculations. Through synergy respective advantages effect of Fe0.96S and carbon, the Fe0.96S@C-S cathode delivers high-rate capability at 5.0 C and stable long-life performance. Even under a high sulfur loading of 3.5 mg/cm2, the durable cyclic stability is still exhibited with the capacity retention of 93% over 400 cycles at 1.0 C, and the coulombic efficiency is ≥98%. Noting that this strategy greatly simplifies the synthetic process of currently known cation-vacancy materials and furnishes a universal mentality for designing both divinable and astonishing new cation-vacancy materials.
